markdownRemark.html:
This tutorial will show you how to build and deploy an application with CloudCamp.

Once you have learned the basics, you will be able to set up any cloud application way faster than by hand or using configuration files. You will learn how to automate all aspects of your app in surprisingly few lines of code - while still having the full flexibility of AWS at your fingertips.

Make sure that CloudCamp is installed and your AWS account is configured.

i
The resources you create in this tutorial are covered by the AWS free tier. When you are done, you can tear down all resources with a single command, leaving your AWS account in a clean state.

The source repository

To learn the basics of CloudCamp, we will deploy a simple web application. Fork the tutorial repository on GitHub, then clone it:

$ git clone git@github.com:YOUR-USERNAME/tutorial.git

Next, change directory and checkout the branch for your language:

$ cd tutorial
$ git checkout typescript
$ cd tutorial
$ git checkout javascript
$ cd tutorial
$ git checkout python
$ cd tutorial
$ git checkout csharp
$ cd tutorial
$ git checkout java

Creating an app

CloudCamp organizes your deployments into "apps" - lightweight infrastructure-as-code programs that live in your project alongside the rest of your application code.

Run camp init to create one:

$ camp init

Set the language to TypeScriptJavaScriptPythonJavaC# and select Continue.

You now have a new directory called cloudcamp in the root of the project that contains your new app at cloudcamp/tutorial.

Let's change directory:

$ cd cloudcamp/tutorial

Deploying to AWS

Now can run deploy:

$ camp deploy

Select Continue and follow the on screen instructions. This will connect your GitHub account and store the access token in your AWS account, so that pushing to your repository can update your application.

When the deploy command has completed, the build process will start.

Run camp status to watch the progress:

$ camp status --wait --notify

ðŸŽ‰ Congratulations! In a few minutes, you created:

  • a build pipeline that deploys your app on a single git push.

  • a load balanced, containerized web server capable of scaling to a large number of machines.

Let's take a look at what we just created.

Infrastructure as Code

CloudCamp is based on Amazon Cloud Development Kit (CDK), a declarative way of building infrastructure. This means that instead of imperatively creating and updating resources, we define a model of what our infrastructure should look like. CDK then takes care of making the necessary changes to accomplish our desired state.

Open up src/camp.tssrc/camp.jssrc/camp.pysrc/Camp.javasrc/Camp.cs in your camp's directory and take a look.

import { App, WebServer } from "@cloudcamp/aws-runtime";
 
let app = new App();
 
new WebServer(app.production, "web", {
  dockerfile: "../../Dockerfile",
  port: 3000,
});
const { App, WebServer } = require("@cloudcamp/aws-runtime");
 
let app = new App();
 
new WebServer(app.production, "web", {
  dockerfile: "../../Dockerfile",
  port: 3000,
});
from cloudcamp.aws_runtime import App, WebServer
 
app = App()
 
WebServer(app.production, "web",
    dockerfile="../../Dockerfile",
    port=3000
)
using Cloudcamp.Aws.Runtime;
 
App app = new App();
 
new WebServer(app.Production, "web", new WebServerProps {
    Dockerfile = "../../Dockerfile",
    Port = 3000
});
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.App;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.WebServer;
 
App app = new App();
 
WebServer.Builder.create(app.getProduction(), "web")
        .dockerfile("../../Dockerfile")
        .port(3000)
        .build();

In the beginning of every program, we instantiate the class App which stands for an instance of our application running in the cloud.

Next, we create a new WebServer, by passing in the parent stack app.production and an identifier "web". Finally, we pass a Dockerfile and a port so our web server knows what to run.

i
App organizes our resources into groups called Stacks that get built and deployed together. Here we make use of a default stack called app.production.

By providing a parent and an identifier when creating a resource, CDK can keep track of our infrastructure and knows when to create new resources or update existing ones.

Adding a database

To add a PostgreSQL database, make the following changes to this source code:

import { App, WebServer, Database } from "@cloudcamp/aws-runtime";
let app = new App();
 
// â¬‡ 1) add a postgres database to the production stack
let productionDb = new Database(app.production, "db", {
  engine: "postgres",
});
 
new WebServer(app.production, "web", {
  dockerfile: "../../Dockerfile",
  port: 3000,
  // â¬‡ 2) add the database url to the environment variables of our webserver
  environment: { DATABASE_URL: productionDb.databaseUrl },
});
const { App, WebServer, Database } = require("@cloudcamp/aws-runtime");
let app = new App();
 
// â¬‡ 1) add a postgres database to the production stack
let productionDb = new Database(app.production, "db", {
  engine: "postgres",
});
 
new WebServer(app.production, "web", {
  dockerfile: "../../Dockerfile",
  port: 3000,
  // â¬‡ 2) add the database url to the environment variables of our webserver
  environment: { DATABASE_URL: productionDb.databaseUrl },
});
from cloudcamp.aws_runtime import App, WebServer, Database
app = App()
 
# â¬‡ 1) add a postgres database to the production stack
production_db = Database(app.production, "db",
    engine="postgres"
)
 
WebServer(app.production, "web",
    dockerfile="../../Dockerfile",
    port=3000,
    # â¬‡ 2) add the database url to the environment variables of our webserver
    environment={"DATABASE_URL": production_db.database_url}
)
using Cloudcamp.Aws.Runtime;
App app = new App();
 
// â¬‡ 1) add a postgres database to the production stack
Database productionDb = new Database(app.Production, "db", new DatabaseProps {
    Engine = "postgres"
});
 
new WebServer(app.Production, "web", new WebServerProps {
    Dockerfile = "../../Dockerfile",
    Port = 3000,
    // â¬‡ 2) add the database url to the environment variables of our webserver
    Environment = new Dictionary<string, string> { { "DATABASE_URL", productionDb.DatabaseUrl } }
});
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.App;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.WebServer;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.Database;
App app = new App();
 
// â¬‡ 1) add a postgres database to the production stack
Database productionDb = Database.Builder.create(app.getProduction(), "db")
        .engine("postgres")
        .build();
 
WebServer.Builder.create(app.getProduction(), "web")
        .dockerfile("../../Dockerfile")
        .port(3000)
        // â¬‡ 2) add the database url to the environment variables of our webserver
        .environment(Map.of("DATABASE_URL", productionDb.getDatabaseUrl()))
        .build();

Here we create a database and add it to the production stack. Then we let the web server know about the database by adding the environment variable DATABASE_URL.

Push the code to apply this change and wait for the pipeline to complete:

$ git add -A && git commit -m "add database" && git push
$ camp status --wait --notify

When refreshing our app in the browser we can see that it is now connected to the database.

Setting up monitoring

In a production app, we need to know when things goes wrong - for example, when users encounter a server error. To simulate an error, visit the /error path on your webserver. Now wouldn't it be nice if we got a notification whenever there is an error? The WebServer class provides an API for exactly that.

Here's how to update your code to add error notifications:

import { App, WebServer, Database } from "@cloudcamp/aws-runtime";
 
let app = new App();
 
let productionDb = new Database(app.production, "db", {
  engine: "postgres",
});
 
// â¬‡ assign our WebServer to a variable
let productionWeb = new WebServer(app.production, "web", {
  dockerfile: "../../Dockerfile",
  port: 3000,
  environment: { DATABASE_URL: productionDb.databaseUrl },
});
 
// â¬‡ set up email notifications when there is an application error
productionWeb.addAlarms({
  email: ["youremail@example.com"],
});

    Engine = "postgres"

    Dockerfile = "../../Dockerfile",
    Port = 3000,
    Environment = new Dictionary<string, string> { { "DATABASE_URL", productionDb.DatabaseUrl } }

    Email = new [] { "youremail@example.com" }

import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.App;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.WebServer;
import cloudcamp.aws.runtime.Database;
 
App app = new App();
 
Database productionDb = Database.Builder.create(app.getProduction(), "db")
        .engine("postgres")
        .build();
 
// â¬‡ assign our WebServer to a variable
WebServer productionWeb = WebServer.Builder.create(app.getProduction(), "web")
        .dockerfile("../../Dockerfile")
        .port(3000)
        .environment(Map.of("DATABASE_URL", productionDb.getDatabaseUrl()))
        .build();
 
// â¬‡ set up email notifications when there is an application error
productionWeb.addAlarms(WebServerAlarmProps.builder()
        .email(List.of("youremail@example.com"))
        .build());

Now update the app - you know the drill.

$ git add -A && git commit -m "add monitoring" && git push
$ camp status --wait --notify

Visit /error again, and you will get an email notification that something went wrong. Neat.

Custom domain (Optional)

Domains and certificates have to be added via the command line before being used. Use domain:create to set up a domain:

$ camp domain:create yourdomain.com

And push your changes:

$ git add -A && git commit -m "add custom domain" && git push
$ camp status --wait --notify

Now, your app will be running under your custom domain.

Cleaning up

To delete all resources we created during this tutorial, run destroy in your camps directory:

$ camp destroy

CloudCamp will list and upon confirmation destroy all the resources you created.

If you added a custom domain, use this command to delete the DNS zone:

$ camp domain:delete yourdomain.com
